title: I have my 341 meeting next month and plan to sign a reaffirmation agreement for my car loan.
question: I have missed a few payments in the past and have incurred some late fees. I only owe $3000 on my car. Any advice for negotiating with lender on reducing my balance or waiving late fees? Also, what does the court consider when approving the reaffirmation agreement? Can the trustee sell my car even if I don't own the title yet?
answers:
You do not need to be current to reaffirm a debt on a car. You only need the creditor to offer one. There is usually no negotiating done. If you are behind and the creditor does not offer one, your vehicle will be subject to repossession not long after the hearing. The Bankruptcy Code requires you to state in your statement of intention that you plan to reaffirm and then gives you a limited amount of time after your hearing to enter into an agreement or the protection terminates.

If you are offered one and you sign it, your attorney, if have one, will have to decide whether to sign or not. If not, the court may not have the power to review it. If you have no attorney, the court will hold a hearing. The courts typically look at whether there is equity, whether the vehicle will likely last long enough to use it, whether your schedules show that you have the income to pay for it and whether it is a burden to reaffirm. If the creditor is offering a deal that you would not otherwise get, then the court may agree to it. If not, it is doubtful.

You said that you owe $3,000 on the car. How much is it worth? If it is worth much less and you can afford to just pay that amount off without borrowing, then redemption might be an option. If not, then redemption is not a good choice. You need to be in a better position after a redemption and you can only do that if the vehicle is worth less than what is owed on it and the amount that you would save more than makes up for the cost of the redemption.

If you are current on your car payments and the lender sends you a reaffirmation agreement the bankruptcy judge will be looking at your ability to pay the loan. If you do not have sufficient funds to pay your living expenses then the judge will not approve the reaffirmation agreement. A good place to look is at your schedule I and J, did you list the car payment? and looking at the bottom of J is there any disposable income left at the end of the month? You can also reaffirm a debt by just making the payment after the filing of the bankruptcy. Since you owe so little your lender might not even require a formal reaffirmation agreement.

Chapter 7 Bankruptcy

If the vehicle is worth less than $3000, have you considered redeeming the vehicle? Under section 722 you can arrange to pay off the loan for the fair market value of the vehicle. There are many lenders out there who specialize in such arrangements.

You need to be current and up to date on the car if you are in a chapter 7. The court will consider whether, based on whether you have any disposable income left after subtracting your Schedule J expenses from your Schedule I Income, you have enough money left over to pay the car payments without creating a hardship. If it is your car, that the registry is holding the title, will not stop the trustee from selling the car if it is deemend appropriate.

This is a general answer to your question. Bankruptcy requires review of your entire financial situation including all debts, income and assets. I highly recommend that you seek representation from an attorney in your jurisdiction who is experienced in bankruptcy law.
